0: LONDON (Reuters) - The parents of terminally ill baby Charlie Gard on Tuesday accused a London hospital of preventing their son from coming home to die, the latest harrowing confrontation in a legal battle that has raised emotions far and wide. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Great Ormond Street Hospital’s lawyer told the High Court it had moved “heaven and earth” to allow 11-month-old Charlie to go home, but this was impossible for practical reasons. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The judge said transferring Charlie to a hospice for his last moments -- a move supported by the hospital -- appeared the most realistic option. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The plight of Charlie, who suffers from a rare genetic condition causing progressive brain damage and muscle weakness, has been at the center of a bitter dispute between his parents and the hospital. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The case has triggered a debate on social media and in the press about whether doctors, judges or parents should decide a child’s fate. U.S. President Donald Trump and Pope Francis are among many people who have weighed in with views. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Staff at Great Ormond Street, a hospital so revered in Britain that it was featured in the opening ceremony of the 2012 London Olympics, have received death threats and abuse. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Emotions are as high in this case as they could be in any,” said the presiding judge, Nicholas Francis. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He gave Charlie’s legal team until Wednesday to see if they could find an intensive care team willing to look after Charlie at his home or at a hospice for several days, in accordance with the parents’ wishes. His parents, Chris Gard and Connie Yates, resigned themselves to letting him die after the most recent set of scans showed his condition had deteriorated to the point no recovery was possible. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The couple want Charlie to be taken to their home or to the home of a close relative or friend for his last moments until his life support system is switched off. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Their lawyer, Grant Armstrong, told the London High Court that Great Ormond Street was placing “obstacle after obstacle” in the way of the parents’ wish. The parents had wanted four days with Charlie before his death, Gollop said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Tuesday’s proceedings were the latest in an agonizing series of court hearings. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Charlie’s parents had wanted to take him to the United States to undergo an experimental treatment never before tried on anyone with his condition, against the advice of Great Ormond Street doctors. Britain’s courts, backed by the European Court of Human Rights, refused permission, saying it would prolong his suffering without any realistic prospect of helping him. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The details of Tuesday’s hearing suggested that the relationship between the parents and the hospital had broken down completely. The hospital said the parents had rejected an offer of mediation.
